name: Grim Dawn

reviews: As a Diablo lover who's too old for Torchlight, too stupid for PoE 2 and too burnt by whatever Diablo 4 is, Grim Dawn was a fun time.

For someone who has played the game for 1000+ hours is a 10/10.
Although the game is outdated when it comes to graphics it still looks good.
Game play, controls and mechanics of the game is really good.
The developer is continuously doing major updates for the game.
This is more addicting to play versus D2R but it wont win againts POE.
The skill tree is not as complicated as POE but almost the same as D2R.
There are a lot of classes to choose from melee, range, summon, magic, DOT, etc..
Each has its own choice of sub build for attack or magic type damage.
Just being a tank with a retaliation build works here, basically standing and let the monsters die when they attack.
The story of the game is also good, especially the DLC of the game is so good its worth it.

This is the the best single player ARPG out there. If what you are looking for in an ARPG is build variety, replayability, and tons of meaningful loot, this game is for you. Don't bother with the bigger names out there. Crate has actively supported this game for 9 years (it looks great) and still has a major expansion on the horizon. This is not an MMO which means no microtransactions, no wonky action house economy, no shifting meta. You can still play multiplayer with up to three of your friends, though (similar to the old Torchlight II). The best part of the game is all the builds work. You won't have to look up some 500 skill point allocation guide to religiously follow (did I mention respec is dirt cheap :). TLDR: Best implementation of an ARPG I have ever seen.

This game is almost a decade old, still gets updates and has less paid DLC BS than games still in Early Access.

Worth

GD is a game I keep coming back to after about 600 hours spent in PoE2 and who-knows-how-many hours spent in PoE1, D3, Dungeon Siege, Chronicon, etc. A lot of the stuff that came about well after D2. Live service model games need to continually make decisions based on what will sell microtransactions - sometimes that means having players do chores to keep them in-game, sometimes it means limited inventory and stash space to sell "quality of life" microtransactions, sometimes it means more aggressive advertising. There's none of that here and it's very refreshing. I get the sense that nearly every decision made by the team is purely devoted to making the player experience the best it can possibly be while retaining all of the classic appeal of a good loot and class-based ARPG. The team doesn't compromise because they don't have to. Power fantasies are in full effect, gearing is fun, endgame is great, and if I ever get tired of any of this you can bet I'll start modding the crap out of this game.

Grim Dawn - A Masterpiece of ARPG Brilliance!

Grim Dawn is an absolute gem in the ARPG genre—fast-paced, deep, and incredibly rewarding. The combat feels visceral and satisfying, with tons of build diversity thanks to the dual-class system and epic loot. The dark, gritty atmosphere is immersive, and the world design is packed with secrets and lore.

Compared to Path of Exile 2, Grim Dawn is just so much more engaging. POE2 feels sluggish and overly complicated, with slow combat that drains the fun out of grinding. Grim Dawn, on the other hand, keeps the action intense and progression meaningful without unnecessary bloat.

And here’s the funny thing—you don’t even realize how good Grim Dawn is until you try POE2. After slogging through POE2’s clunky pacing and tedious mechanics, you suddenly appreciate Grim Dawn’s smooth combat, rewarding loot system, and player-friendly design. It’s like going back to a perfectly cooked steak after eating plain oatmeal.

If you want an ARPG that respects your time and delivers constant excitement, Grim Dawn is the way to go!

[h1]Grim Dawn – Solid Foundation, But Wears Thin Over Time[/h1]
I'd put this between thumbs up and thumbs-down. Thumbs-up if its on a deep-sale (which is what I bought it on, so ultimately I'm happy).

Grim Dawn held my interest for a little while, but it quickly became repetitive to the point where it started to feel more like a chore than fun. The gameplay loop didn’t evolve much, which made progression feel a bit monotonous as time went on.

The early game also felt particularly slow, with a sluggish progression curve that made it harder to stay engaged from the outset.

I didn’t enjoy the camera controls or field of vision either—it felt more restrictive compared to other ARPGs I’ve played. Tree canopies and building facades often obscure visibility to the point where I found myself wrestling with the camera more than focusing on the actual gameplay.

Visually, the game’s graphics feel quite dated, and while functional, they don’t do much to elevate the experience.

I’ll likely finish my current playthrough with my first character and might check out the DLC quests, but I don’t see myself rushing to do another run with a different character.

short_description: Enter an apocalyptic fantasy world where humanity is on the brink of extinction, iron is valued above gold and trust is hard earned. This ARPG features complex character development, hundreds of unique items, crafting and quests with choice & consequence.
